title: Business & Finance
text:
Executives running some of the world's biggest retailers, manufacturers and consumer-products makers say they are seeing signs that people are becoming less willing to absorb price increases.

---

The largest U.S. banks, securities firms and custodians, many of which once greeted cryptocurrencies skeptically, are now showcasing their forays into the market.

---

Florida's stripping Disney of its special taxing privileges leaves investors wondering who pays back almost $1 billion of municipal bonds.

The fallout from the spat between Disney and DeSantis alarmed corporate leaders, according to executives and their advisers.

---

Buffett called markets over the past few years "a gambling parlor," as Berkshire Hathaway makes new investments after a period of relative quiet.

Berkshire's quarterly earnings fell as market turbulence weighed on its stock portfolio and rising claims costs hurt its insurance-underwriting business.

---

Rampant inflation is helping reduce the weight of the world's public debt relative to its economic output, a boon for governments that economists warn could backfire if inflation stays unchecked.
